user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_FileSysStatVolume:
```c
int32 OS_FileSysStatVolume(const char *name, OS_statvfs_t *statbuf)
{
    int32             return_code;
    OS_object_token_t token;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_PATHNAME(name);
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(statbuf);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, OS_FileSys_FindVirtMountPoint,
                                         (void *)name, &token);

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_FileSysStatVolume_Impl(&token, statbuf);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_FileSysStatVolume:
#define OS_CHECK_PATHNAME(str) OS_CHECK_STRING(str,OS_MAX_PATH_LEN,OS_FS_ERR_PATH_TOO_LONG)
...
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t MatchFunc, void *arg,
                             OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdFindNextMatch(MatchFunc, arg, token);

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "lock_mode" parameter.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }
    else
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
bool OS_FileSys_FindVirtMountPoint(void *ref, const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_common_record_t *obj)
{
    OS_filesys_internal_record_t *filesys;
    const char *                  target = (const char *)ref;
    size_t                        mplen;

    filesys = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_filesys_table, *token);

    if ((filesys->flags & OS_FILESYS_FLAG_IS_MOUNTED_VIRTUAL) == 0)
    {
        return false;
    }

    mplen = OS_strnlen(filesys->virtual_mountpt, sizeof(filesys->virtual_mountpt));

    /*
     * The virtual_mountpt member should be a substring of the search target.
     * If this matches a basic substring check then it may be match
     */
    if (mplen == 0 || mplen >= sizeof(filesys->virtual_mountpt) ||
        strncmp(target, filesys->virtual_mountpt, mplen) != 0)
    {
        /* not a substring, so not a match */
        return false;
    }

    /*
     * Confirm that the substring ends at either a directory separator
     * or the end of string  (so exact mount points also match).
     *
     * For instance consider a virtual_mountpt of /mnt/abc and searching
     * for target=/mnt/abcd - this should return false in that case.
     */
    return (target[mplen] == '/' || target[mplen] == 0);
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
int32 OS_FileSysStatVolume_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_statvfs_t *result)
{
    OS_filesys_internal_record_t *local;
    struct statvfs                stat_buf;

    local = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_filesys_table, *token);

    if (statvfs(local->system_mountpt, &stat_buf) != 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    result->block_size   = OSAL_SIZE_C(stat_buf.f_bsize);
    result->blocks_free  = OSAL_BLOCKCOUNT_C(stat_buf.f_bfree);
    result->total_blocks = OSAL_BLOCKCOUNT_C(stat_buf.f_blocks);

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
typedef struct
{
    size_t            block_size;   /**< Block size of underlying FS */
    osal_blockcount_t total_blocks; /**< Total blocks in underlying FS */
    osal_blockcount_t blocks_free;  /**< Available blocks in underlying FS */
} OS_statvfs_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I examined all provided code fragments and found no code that is provably unreachable for all possible inputs or configurations. Rationale by fragment:

- OS_FileSysStatVolume: control flow is straightforward — parameter checks, a call to OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch, conditional processing when that returns OS_SUCCESS, and a final return of return_code. There is no code after an unconditional return or other construct that would make any statement unreachable for all inputs.

- OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch: both branches of the if/else are reachable depending on the return value from OS_ObjectIdFindNextMatch; no dead code after an unconditional transfer of control.

- OS_FileSys_FindVirtMountPoint: all return statements are conditional and reachable depending on runtime data (flags, mplen, strncmp result, and target content). The final return expression is reached when the earlier guards pass.

- OS_FileSysStatVolume_Impl: the function returns OS_ERROR when statvfs fails and OS_SUCCESS after populating result on success; both paths are reachable depending on the statvfs result.

- OS_ObjectIdRelease and OS_statvfs_t: trivial and contain no unreachable code.

Notes for reviewers (not flagged as suspicious fragments but worth confirming):
- The macros OS_CHECK_PATHNAME/OS_CHECK_POINTER expand to checks that invoke BUGCHECK (and OS_CHECK_STRING). If BUGCHECK is implemented as a non-returning construct (e.g., infinite loop, longjmp, or abort), that is a deliberate error-handling termination and does not by itself imply unreachable code in the rest of the function (those subsequent statements are reachable for valid arguments). However, to fully satisfy MISRA Rule 2.1 you should confirm the actual definitions of BUGCHECK and OS_CHECK_STRING to ensure they do not introduce unconditional non-local control flow that would make surrounding code unreachable in all build configurations.

Given the provided code, there are no code fragments that must be investigated for unreachable code; only the macro implementations mentioned above should be reviewed to ensure they do not inadvertently create unreachable code across the project.
